title: Tour de France : Spanish winners until 2018
summary: This is a bar chart representing Cyclists in the x axis and Number of victories in the y axis.
The Number of victories is highest at Cyclists Miguel Induráin (1991 1992 1993 1994 and 1995) and lowest at Cyclists Carlos Sastre (2008).
The highest Cyclists Miguel Induráin (1991 1992 1993 1994 and 1995) has 4.0 more Number of victories than the lowest Cyclists Carlos Sastre (2008).
min_summary: This is a bar chart. It shows Number of victories for 7 number of Cyclistss.
The Number of victories is appeared to be the highest at Cyclists Miguel Induráin (1991 1992 1993 1994 and 1995) and lowest at Cyclists Carlos Sastre (2008).
mid_summary: This is a bar chart representing Cyclists in the x axis and Number of victories in the y axis.
The Number of victories is highest at Cyclists Miguel Induráin (1991 1992 1993 1994 and 1995) and lowest at Cyclists Carlos Sastre (2008).
The highest Cyclists Miguel Induráin (1991 1992 1993 1994 and 1995) has 4.0 more Number of victories than the lowest Cyclists Carlos Sastre (2008).
max_summary: This bar chart has 7 columns on the x axis representing Cyclists, and Number of victories in each Cyclists on the y axis.
The Number of victories is appeared to be the highest at Cyclists Miguel Induráin (1991 1992 1993 1994 and 1995) and lowest at Cyclists Carlos Sastre (2008).
The second highest Number of victories is appeared to be the Cyclists Alberto Contador (2007 and 2009).
The highest Cyclists Miguel Induráin (1991 1992 1993 1994 and 1995) has 4.0 more Number of victories than the lowest Cyclists Carlos Sastre (2008).

Cyclists Miguel Induráin (1991 1992 1993 1994 and 1995) is higher than any other Cyclistss with value 5.0, followed by Alberto Contador (2007 and 2009), and Federico Martín Bahamontes (1959). Down to Cyclists Carlos Sastre (2008) with the lowest value 1.0.
Similar Number of victories is found in Cyclists Carlos Sastre (2008), Óscar Pereiro (2006), Perico Delgado (1988), Luis Ocaña (1973), and Federico Martín Bahamontes (1959).
The lowest value 1.0 at Carlos Sastre (2008) is almost 2.92 times smaller than the average value 1.71.
